sourcesContent:
import React from 'react'; class Strings extends React.Component{ constructor(props){ super(props) } render(){ return (
As we learned on the variables page, Strings are used to store text and are denoted using double quotation marks. Strings are different from the other variable types that we have learned about so far â€“ integers, doubles, characters, booleans. (btw: the difference you may have noticed is that String has a capital first letter whereas int, double, char, and boolean are all lowercase.) Strings are special, and that's why we've dedicated a whole page to them!

hello world

primitive types

HELLO world

Let's learn how to make "heLlO woRlD" into "hello world" or "HELLO WORLD". In other words, let's learn how to make a String all lowercase or all UPPERCASE.
You can use toLowerCase() and toUpperCase() to make a String all lowercase or all UPPERCASE, respectively:
String myStr = "we LOVE Strings!";
String myLowerCaseStr = myStr.toLowerCase();
//make myStr all lowercase

String myUpperCaseStr = myStr.toUpperCase();
//make myStr all uppercase

//print out the lowercase and uppercase versions of myStr

System.out.println(myLowerCaseStr);
System.out.println(myUpperCaseStr);
the code above prints out the following in the console (psst. need a reminder on why System.out.println() outputs something to the console? check out the printing page!):
we love strings!
WE LOVE STRINGS!
(btw: numbers and symbols, like the exclamation mark above, do not get affected by toLowerCase() and toUpperCase().)

h e l l o w o r l d

let's redefine what a String is: a String is just a bunch of characters.

hello wo

hello + world

hello world... more like hello recap

YASSS! you made it to recap!
...we know just for java is as addicting as the newest Netflix binge, so what are you waiting for? keep coding!
) } } export default Strings;
